abstract.p: Cynthia Rosenzweig letter on John Tierney's Dec 7 column urges New York region to prepare for serious challenges posed by global warming0

block.p: In ''Warming Up to the Notion of Warming'' (Big City column, Dec. 7), John Tierney repeats the conclusion of Robert O. Mendelsohn, an economist, that global warming won't be so bad for New York. But the researchers and agency representatives who participated with me in a recent assessment agree that the trend poses serious challenges for the region.

The effects will be widespread but uneven, with the greatest impact on the elderly, the poor and those in coastal areas. Storm surges may threaten infrastructure. Other problems include deaths from heat and increased summer energy demands that will affect air quality and costs.

But the researchers and agency representatives who participated with me in a recent assessment agree that the trend poses serious challenges for the region.

The effects will be widespread but uneven, with the greatest impact on the elderly, the poor and those in coastal areas. Storm surges may threaten infrastructure. Other problems include deaths from heat and increased summer energy demands that will affect air quality and costs.
The most severe effects will come later this century, but planning and prevention should start now. Fortunately, decision makers in the area are embracing the concept.
The writer is a research scientist at NASA and the Columbia Earth Institute.
